title: Fracking-Services Company FTS International Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Texas-based company enters chapter 11 with prepackaged plan that swaps $440 million in debt for majority of its equity. Fracking-services company FTS International Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday after reaching an agreement with creditors on a debt-for-equity swap following a downturn in the energy sector and lower demand for its services.

title: N.Y. City Council Introduces Bills to Aid Restaurants in Coronavirus Recovery
summary: The most prominent bill would establish a permanent outdoor-dining program. The New York City Council is considering several bills that would aid restaurants as they try to recover from the economic hit brought on by the new coronavirus pandemic, including one that would make sidewalk and curbside street dining permanent.

title: Biden and the Supreme Court
summary: He refuses to say if he'd go along with his party's court-packing scheme.. 'The voters of this country should be heard," Joe Biden said this weekend as he exhorted Senate Republicans to block a vote on President Trump's Supreme Court nominee. That might be clever messaging-who doesn't want voters to be heard? But there's one problem: Unlike Mr. Trump and Senate Republicans, Mr. Biden has given so few details about his Supreme Court vision that voters are left guessing at what a vote for him means for the judiciary.

title: The Xinjiang Model Comes to Tibet
summary: Beijing denies ill-treatment but bars unmonitored visitors.. The Communist Party's oppression of Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang has tarnished China's image and complicated its relationship with countless countries. Yet a report from the Jamestown Foundation published Tuesday says Beijing is extending this repression by bringing some of the same coercive tactics to Tibet.

title: Will a 'Blue Shift' Swing Wisconsin?
summary: A judge orders ballots counted until Nov. 9, nixing timely results.. Here we go again: Absentee votes in Wisconsin are due by Election Day, state law says. But on Monday a federal judge ordered the counting of ballots that arrive by Nov. 9, provided their postmarks say Nov. 3. After similar rulings in Pennsylvania and Michigan, none of the big three swing states from 2016 seems likely to have solid results on election night. It's no accident that the lawsuits in all three states have been backed by Democrats.

title: Sheldon Whitehouse Goes Dark
summary: The Senator refuses to take questions about his own dark-money ties.. We didn't know Sheldon Whitehouse scared so easily. Our editorial Tuesday laid out questions to ask the Rhode Island Senator about his own dark-money ties when he testified before a House Judiciary subcommittee. At the event he refused to answer, and Democratic Chairman Hank Johnsonlet him get away with it.

title: Avianca Nets $2 Billion in Bankruptcy Loans
summary: The financing package is backed by LifeMiles, Avianca's valuable loyalty program. Avianca Holdings SA, one of Latin America's largest airlines, lined up a $2 billion bankruptcy-loan package to finance its stay in chapter 11 from a group of investors and lenders including United Airlines Inc. and Chairman Roberto Kriete.

title: What's Happening With TikTok and WeChat?
summary: TikTok and WeChat users in the U.S. were granted a reprieve from potential bans of the apps, but uncertainty remains. TikTok and WeChat users in the U.S. have been granted a reprieve from potential bans of the apps, but for different reasons. TikTok, owned by Beijing-based ByteDance Ltd., will partner with Oracle Corp. and Walmart Inc. to become a U.S.-based company.

title: Xinjiang Is No Disneyland
summary: Students debate the responsibility of Big Business to stand up to China.. Editor's note: In this Future View, students discuss the duty of companies that do business in China, in light of the controversy over Disney 's "Mulan." Next week we'll launch a series of election-themed questions, beginning with the big picture: "What one issue does the U.S. election boil down to?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Sept. 29. The best responses will be published that night.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Tops 200,000
summary: Grim milestone is reached as some guidelines and practices for stopping disease's spread have been questioned. More than 200,000 people in the U.S. have died from Covid-19, a grim milestone as Americans enter another new season with a pandemic that continues to shape every facet of life.

title: China Backslides on Economic Reform
summary: Under Xi Jinping, Beijing hasn't liberalized. It's doubled down on politically directed state capitalism.. China is the only major world economy reporting any economic growth today. It went first into Covid-19 and was first out, grinding out 3.2% growth in the most recent quarter while the U.S. shrank 9.5% and other advanced economies endured double-digit declines. High-tech monitoring, comprehensive testing and aggressive top-down containment measures enabled China to get the virus under control while others struggled. The Middle Kingdom may even deliver a modest year-over-year economic expansion in 2020.

title: Stand on Precedent. That's a Good Boy!
summary: In 1870 a Missouri lawyer delivered 'A Tribute to a Dog.'. Among the portraits of former justices that hang in the Missouri Supreme Court building in Jefferson City stands the bust of a hound dog named Old Drum. The sculpture isn't meant as a homage to a canine. Rather, it is a tribute to a lawyer.

title: Hispanic Voters May Provide the Margin in November
summary: Will Trump's improving poll numbers be enough to neutralize Biden's natural advantage?. President Trump has said he will nominate a replacement for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg later this week, and it's no surprise that Judge Barbara Lagoa is high on his short list.

title: 'The Bloody Flag' Review: Seas of Unrest
summary: In the fraught late 18th century, mutiny was a constant threat to the British, French and Dutch fleets of the North Atlantic and the Caribbean.. The 1789 mutiny aboard the Bounty in the course of its scientific expedition in the South Pacific remains the most famous maritime uprising of its era, and perhaps of all time. But in "The Bloody Flag: Mutiny in the Age of Atlantic Revolution," Niklas Frykman portrays an era of lower-deck turbulence of far greater magnitude. In the midst of the French Revolutionary Wars (1792-1802), mutiny was a constant threat to the British, French and Dutch fleets of the North Atlantic and the Caribbean. Mr. Frykman, an assistant professor of history at the University of Pittsburgh, estimates that by the early 1800s, from one-third to one-half of seamen in the North Atlantic had been involved in at least one mutiny.

title: Notable & Quotable: Mitt Romney on the Supreme Court
summary: 'My liberal friends have over many decades gotten very used to the idea of having a liberal court, and that's not written in the stars.'. Sen. Mitt Romney (R., Utah) speaking Sept. 22 on the Supreme Court vacancy:

title: Patriots Vote in Person
summary: And your Senate vote can lower the stakes of a presidential recount however long it takes.. Time is needed to exchange pieces of paper through the mail, as Congress understood in the Credit Card Act of 2009. It set a 21-day grace period before interest accrues to your account. It set clear rules for when your payment is complete: when received, not when postmarked. Even so, one voting-like risk doesn't exist: None of us is ever likely to be victimized by a stranger paying off our credit-card bill in our name.

title: Nike's Sales Bounce Back From Coronavirus Slide
summary: Sneaker giant posts flat quarterly revenue as jump in digital sales offsets in-store declines. Nike Inc.'s sales rebounded in the summer quarter after slumping earlier during the coronavirus pandemic, as rising digital sales offset declining revenue at traditional stores.

title: Mnuchin, Powell Urge More Spending to Help Economy Recover
summary: Officials suggest many would-be borrowers need grants, which would require new funding from Congress. The two top U.S. economic officials told lawmakers that emergency loan programs to support the coronavirus-stricken economy were largely working as intended and that more government spending would be needed to sustain the recovery.

title: U.S.-China Rift Worries World Leaders at the United Nations
summary: Rising tensions leave other countries caught in the middle; 'when elephants fight, it is the grass that gets trampled flat'. World leaders sounded alarms Tuesday over the widening rift between the U.S. and China, warning that a lack of cooperation could worsen the coronavirus pandemic, slow a global economic recovery or even lead to outright conflict.

title: CDC Advisory Panel to Delay Vote on Initial Vaccine Rollout
summary: Committee may wait until government authorizes specific vaccine or vaccines before voting on prioritization plan for recipients. A federal vaccine advisory committee will put off a vote on recommending who should get initial limited doses of any Covid-19 vaccine in the U.S. until committee members learn more about the vaccines that could become available first, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Who's Protesting Now?
summary: The New York Times discovers antifa in the suburbs, where another movement is also making noise.. Former Vice President Joe Bidenlikes to pretend that this year's violent protests are largely the work of right-wingers and white supremacists. He'll get another chance to cling to this fantasy in the first presidential debate against Donald Trump, next week in Cleveland.

title: Louisville Police Brace for Decision in Breonna Taylor Shooting Case
summary: Kentucky attorney general expected to announce whether to bring charges against city officers. Louisville police restricted access to the city's downtown ahead of an expected decision by the Kentucky attorney general on whether to bring charges against police officers involved in Breonna Taylor's killing.

title: An Art Museum Sells Its Soul
summary: The Everson Museum of Art, which plans to auction off its prize Pollock painting, is using the laudable aim of funding a more diverse collection as an excuse to betray the public trust..

title: 'A Wilderness of Error' Review: The Absence of Absolutes
summary: A nuanced documentary series on FX revisits the tangled history of the Jeffrey MacDonald murder case.. The only concrete conclusion reached by the engrossing/frustrating "A Wilderness of Error" is that even a guilty man can be deprived of a fair trial. And that when a crime defies logic, the search for the absolute truth about it is, at best, quixotic.

title: French Foreign Minister Says LVMH Query Led to Letter on Tiffany Deal
summary: His remark calls into question earlier statements by the luxury conglomerate about backing out of the deal. PARIS-French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said he was responding to a query from LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE when he wrote a letter to the luxury conglomerate asking it to delay its acquisition of Tiffany & Co.

title: Ford to Build Electric Cars in Canada as Part of Labor Deal
summary: Ford and union set three-year pact that includes $1.5 billion investment in Canadian plants. OTTAWA- Ford Motor Co. has reached a tentative labor deal with its 5,400 unionized employees in Canada that also secures a nearly $1.5 billion investment in two plants and a commitment to build electric cars in suburban Toronto.

title: U.S. Stocks End Higher as S&P 500 Snaps Losing Streak
summary: The recovery follows a bout of volatility that has tested investors' confidence in the market's monthslong rebound. U.S. stocks rose Tuesday, stabilizing after a bout of volatility that had tested investors' confidence in the market's monthslong rebound.

title: Rouhani, Trump Rebuke One Another's Nations on U.N.'s Virtual Stage
summary: Iranian leader says U.S. 'humiliated' itself with failed sanctions effort; Trump boasts of quitting 'terrible' U.N.-blessed nuclear pact. The U.S. and Iranian presidents on Tuesday took their nations' dispute to the virtual world stage, trading attacks over the 2015 multilateral nuclear deal, the U.S. "maximum pressure" campaign, Iran's role in regional security and the U.S. killing of a prominent Iranian military commander in January.

title: Nikola Executive Defends Business Model
summary: Electric-truck firm's partners are staying the course despite allegations by short seller, CFO says. A Nikola Corp. executive defended the electric-truck firm's technology and business plan, telling an investor conference that its partners are staying the course following the departure of its high-profile founder and executive chairman.

title: This Breakthrough Blondie Recipe Will Make You Forget All About Brownies
summary: The topping of caramel almonds sells it, but it's the rich, complex flavor of brown butter in the base that makes this update on classic blondies unforgettable. PRESENTED WITH a blondie and a brownie, most people will reach for the brownie. Top the blondie with a thick layer of sliced almonds suspended in rich caramel, and the odds will tilt sharply in the other direction.

title: Tesla's Battery Day: Why Elon Musk and Other Car Makers Are Fighting Over Batteries
summary: Race is on for power cells that provide greater vehicle range at lower cost. Tesla Inc. Chief Executive Elon Musk on Tuesday will spell out his vision for the future of the company's car batteries. The Silicon Valley electric vehicle maker-along with automotive suppliers and rivals such as General Motors Co.-are on the hunt for batteries that are better and cheaper. Here is what you need to know:

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg and American Business
summary: Here's what the Supreme Court vacancy could mean for U.S. corporations. Editor's note: This is an excerpt from our newsletter, "2020 Election+Business," a weekly dive into the intersection of business, finance and the 2020 election. You can sign up here.

title: 'G is for Gun': Online Curriculum Outrages Parents
summary: Racist, inaccurate content in lessons stirs backlash; Acellus founder denies claims about alleged religious sect. Paige Kemerer opened her school's new online program and saw a lesson that used an image of beer to teach about St. Patrick's Day. Another used the wrong picture for St. Augustine, Fla. And one inaccurately said Rosa Parks was arrested because she didn't sit in the Blacks only section on a bus, instead of correctly noting that she refused to give up her seat to a white man, said Ms. Kemerer, a third-grade teacher at Kapa'a Elementary School on the island of Kauai in Hawaii.

title: How Covid-19 Lockdowns Have Boosted Mother-Daughter Bonds
summary: Some relationships have deepened in the American family during the pandemic, a broad survey suggests; 'We got so much closer'. Instead of going to summer camp this year, Ava Littman hiked on trails with her mother, Tara Cook-Littman, listening to stories about her mom's childhood and opening up about how much she missed her friends.

title: New York City Dealt Legal Blow in Plan to Close Rikers Island
summary: Supreme Court judge sides with residents who oppose new Manhattan jail; city will appeal. A Manhattan judge sided with residents who seek to block construction of a new jail in Chinatown, potentially dealing a blow to Mayor Bill de Blasio's plan to replace the Rikers Island jail complex with smaller detention centers in other boroughs.

title: New York's Online Class Sizes Could Reach Nearly 70 Students
summary: As more families choose remote learning and teacher shortage looms, district allows larger class sizes online. New York Public Schools teacher Kirk Schneider is teaching six online geometry classes, each meeting twice a week. He is also teaching a remote social emotional learning class three times a week, which helps students address personal challenges during the pandemic, with about 25 children in each class.

title: Modern, Minimalist Living Spaces Prove You Can't Judge This Houston Tudor by Its Cover
summary: Behind the design of the home's dining and living rooms, which cost roughly $534,600 to create. It's hard to believe that the modern minimalist dining and living rooms pictured here exist in a 12,263-square-foot French Tudor-style home in Memorial Villages, an affluent section of Houston. "This was an $8 million spec house that we came in and fixed," said Nina Magon, principal and creative director of Contour Interior Design in Houston. The owners, the co-head of an energy investment company and a rheumatologist with two young children, love to entertain and asked Ms. Magon to incorporate "stand-out pieces that look like art" from "top designer brands" in the design of the two rooms. Which she did, at a total cost of about $534,600. "It's a little different for this area. You generally don't see spaces designed like this," said Ms. Magon of the results. "The rest of Houston will have to catch up to this design." Here are some of the rooms' costs.

title: U.K. Introduces New Covid-19 Restrictions to Curb Second Wave
summary: Government urges people to work from home, limits pub hours, reverses plan to open sporting events to public. LONDON-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a series of new coronavirus restrictions for England, including earlier pub-closing times, as his government tries to quell a second wave of infections while avoiding another economically damaging nationwide lockdown.

title: Two N.Y. Men Accused of Trading on Inside Information From S&P Dow Jones Indices
summary: Yinghang 'James' Yang, a senior index manager, and his friend, Yuanbiao Chen, were accused of running the scheme for several months last year. Two New York men are accused of making more than $900,000 in an insider-trading scheme, using confidential information on publicly traded companies from the S&P Dow Jones Indices, the company that manages the S&P 500 benchmark and other indexes.

title: World Leaders Address Covid-19 Crisis at U.N. General Assembly
summary: President Trump blames China for the pandemic while Beijing and others implore nations to work together to fight the virus. Heads of state and United Nations leaders addressed the U.N. General Assembly on Tuesday on the Covid-19 pandemic, laying blame and finding fault -and imploring the body to work together to fight the virus. Here are some excerpts:

title: Getting the Census Right: A Bipartisan Issue
summary: The Census Bureau itself has indicated there is the potential for "serious errors" in the data if it is forced to deliver its findings by Dec. 31.. Your editorial "The Next Census Brawl" (Sept. 14) implies that Democrats are the only ones concerned with a shortened Census count, but the Census Bureau itself has indicated there is the potential for "serious errors" in the data if it is forced to deliver its findings by Dec. 31.

title: Aluminum Tariff Hurt U.S. Manufacturing
summary: Aluminum from Canada is critically important to U.S. manufacturing and defense capabilities, as the U.S. doesn't have the domestic production capacity to fulfill demand.. Your editorial "An Aluminum Tariff Reprieve" (Sept. 17) makes good note of the political motives of the U.S. Trade Representative's substitution of the highly unpopular aluminum tariffs on Canada with arbitrary quotas that will not impact Americans until after Election Day. However, while the USTR's announcement may have kicked the political can further down the road, the notion that the "tariff reprieve spares manufacturers and consumers for now," unfortunately neglects the long-term effects the tariffs have already inflicted on U.S. manufacturers. Aluminum from Canada is critically important to U.S. manufacturing and defense capabilities, as the U.S. doesn't have the domestic production capacity to fulfill demand, especially during a global pandemic that has strained supply chains.

title: Rittenhouse, Facebook and President Trump
summary: Assuming President Trump's assertions that Facebook is full of fake news and slam pieces, why shouldn't Facebook be actively working on its censorship algorithms and policies?. Regarding your editorial "Facebook's Rittenhouse Mistake" (Sept. 5): By tweeting his thoughts on guilt versus innocence in the Kyle Rittenhouse case, the president of our un-United States has done more to tamper with potential jury pools than Facebook ever could by censoring content about the case.

title: Remote Classes Need Good Internet Service
summary: Community Networks can serve as a viable solution for expanding internet access in the U.S. and around the world.. The lack of broadband internet access in West Virginia is a microcosm of a global issue ("Online Classes Are Offline for Many," U.S. News, Sept. 14). Almost half of the world's population lacks access to the internet, but many people are unaware of the extent of the digital divide.

title: Apartment Startup Common Bets on Expansion Despite Pandemic
summary: The co-living and rental-apartment management company completed the raising of $50 million in new venture capital. Apartment rents in big cities are dropping, but some entrepreneurs and venture investors are still making long-term bets on the housing industry.

title: Stock Valuation Tool Loses Accuracy at Very Low Rates
summary: As the capitalization/discount rate approaches zero, the present value approaches infinity.. "Bond Yields Encourage Risk Taking" (Business & Finance, Sept. 15) says that one reason for the stock rally is that "in formulas used to estimate what stock prices should be, lower yields help pull down the so-called discount rate . . . [which] makes future corporate earnings more valuable."

title: Is There Life After a TikTok Ban? A Nation Goes Into Withdrawal
summary: Bereft fans in India, where TikTok was banned this summer, say other apps just aren't the same. NEW DELHI - American fans of TikTok have recently been left pondering a possible future without their favorite short-video sharing app. India knows what that future looks like, and it isn't pretty.

title: Will Working From Home Kill the Bra Forever?
summary: A historical perspective on the underpinning that is losing traction during the pandemic. WORN A BRA LATELY? Both anecdotal evidence and sagging sales figures suggest that, in the era of WFH and its corollary, a repudiation of any hint of containment, many women are answering "no" to that question. Which is why this column will focus not on a garment that's being worn but one that's been cast aside.

title: Oil Market Flies Blind as Virus Clouds Demand Outlook
summary: Lack of visibility has contributed to renewed turbulence in the market after prices rose over the summer. Predicting oil demand has rarely been more challenging, buffeting prices and muddying the outlook for traders, investors and energy producers.

title: Designed for the Digital Stage
summary: American opera companies, including Houston Grand Opera, have begun to create original content for virtual viewing..

title: University of California Admitted Less Qualified but Well-Connected Students
summary: More than 20 of the students were inappropriately tagged as athletic recruits; report says admissions controls were particularly weak at Berkeley. The University of California system admitted dozens of applicants with connections to donors and employees over better qualified candidates in recent years, the state's auditor said Tuesday.

title: Explosion Rocks Hezbollah Stronghold in Lebanon
summary: Blast comes as nation is still recovering from deadly explosion last month that destroyed parts of Beirut. BEIRUT-A large explosion shook a Hezbollah stronghold in southern Lebanon on Tuesday, sending a thick plume of smoke over a country still reeling from the deadly Beirut explosion last month that devastated parts of the capital.

title: New York Regulator Pushes Insurers on Climate Change
summary: The effort comes amid concerns that severe weather related to climate change is spurring more losses for insurance companies. One of New York state's top financial watchdogs urged insurers to better manage the risks they face from climate change, joining other regulators world-wide raising alarms about the shocks severe weather could cause the financial system.

title: U.S. Home Sales Extended Powerful Rebound Into August
summary: Sales rose 10.5% on annual basis, putting the summer's housing market well ahead of last year's sales levels. Home sales rose in August for the third consecutive month, fueled by robust demand for luxury homes and a pickup in Northeast sales that kept the housing market hot.

title: Davos Organizers Seek New Site After Postponing Meeting
summary: World Economic Forum says the annual gathering is still on for next summer, but will take place elsewhere in Switzerland. The World Economic Forum won't be meeting in Davos at all in 2021 after initially postponing its annual session in January because of the coronavirus crisis, and it is now looking at other locations elsewhere in Switzerland for the gathering.

title: Looking for a New Couch on the Cheap? Welcome to 'Stooping' Instagram
summary: Scavengers looking for free furniture are following postings on the platform to find items, but they have to act fast. As the coronavirus pandemic has prompted some residents to leave big cities-and their furniture-behind, more people are using Instagram to seek out abandoned curbside items, from couches to houseplants. People working from home, eager for a change of desk-front scenery and out-of-work residents on tight budgets have added to the "stooping" competition. Instagram accounts dedicated to aggregating pictures and locations of discarded furniture are popping up in cities like New York City, Philadelphia, Richmond, Va., and Amsterdam. Savvy users can find pieces that would be worth thousands of dollars new-if they act fast. "I got there 35 minutes after multiple items had been posted and every single thing was gone," said "stooper" Natasha Lekwa, 32, a Williamsburg business consultant. "I was like OK, 'I gotta get on my game.' "

title: NBCUniversal's Cable Channels Were a Crown Jewel. Now They're an 'Albatross.'
summary: With channels like E!, Oxygen and Syfy on borrowed time, media company pushes deep cuts and centralizes program decisions. For years, NBCUniversal's cable networks, channels like USA, Bravo and E!, were power centers in the media company, each with a mandate to promote their own programming and brands.

title: Most Republicans Back Trump on Moving Forward With Supreme Court Nominee
summary: With two exceptions, GOP senators fall in behind party leaders. Senate Republicans have largely lined up behind President Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) in moving ahead with a Supreme Court nomination ahead of Election Day.

title: Covid-19 Can Keep AutoZone in the Fast Lane
summary: With more drivers sticking with older cars and taking on do-it-yourself repair projects, AutoZone is in the right place at the right time.. There are only a few places where investors seem to be driving defensively despite impressive growth. Auto-parts retail is one of them.

title: Maine to Use Ranked-Choice Voting in Presidential Race
summary: State's highest court says GOP failed to get enough signatures for a 'people's veto' referendum. PORTLAND, Maine-Ranked-choice voting will be used for the first time in a presidential race under a ruling Tuesday by the Maine Supreme Court, which concluded a GOP petition drive came up short.

title: At 16, Kim Cattrall Moved Alone to New York to Study Acting
summary: The 'Filthy Rich' star reflects on leaving Liverpool for Canada, discovering the theater and why 'Sex and the City' didn't appeal to her at first. Kim Cattrall, 64, is an actress best known for her role as Samantha in "Sex and the City." She stars in Fox's satirical drama series "Filthy Rich." She spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Ralph Lauren to Cut 15% of Workforce After Coronavirus Lockdowns Reduced Demand
summary: Steep revenue drop and $127 million quarterly loss reflect store closings during the pandemic. Ralph Lauren Corp. said it would cut its workforce by roughly 15%, reflecting a sharp drop in revenue tied to coronavirus-related store closures earlier this year and potential challenges ahead, as economies in different markets try to recover.

title: A Little Debate on Plasma Is Healthy for Science
summary: The FDA says it's likely effective, while NIH urges caution. The answer: Get more data from trials.. By now many have heard about the debate over convalescent plasma as an effective treatment for Covid-19. On Aug. 23, the FDA issued an Emergency Use Authorization stating that convalescent plasma-extracted from the blood of recovered patients-"may be effective" in hospitalized patients and can be used in the current emergency. The agency stopped short of fully authorizing or licensing convalescent plasma. But on Sept. 1 a National Institutes of Health panel argued that the data were insufficient "to recommend either for or against" use of plasma.

title: Republicans Play With Fire on the Court
summary: Most voters want the next president to fill the seat and may punish GOP senators.. The fight over replacing Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has added fuel to a raging political fire. President Trump evidently believes that swiftly announcing his choice and pushing for a vote will improve his re-election prospects; the opening is deflecting public attention from the Covid-19 pandemic. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who regards a transformed federal judiciary as his principal legacy, is equally committed to replacing Justice Ginsburg.

title: Amazon Restricts Ad Buying by Rivals
summary: Resume Subscription. Amazon.com Inc. is limiting the ability of some competitors to promote their rival smart speakers, video doorbells and other devices on its dominant e-commerce platform, according to Amazon employees and executives at rival companies and advertising firms.

title: Soho Scores Its Priciest-Ever Deal With $35.14 Million Penthouse Sale
summary: The transaction is one of the most expensive to close in New York City since the coronavirus pandemic hit. In one of the largest New York City deals to close since the pandemic, a Soho penthouse has sold for $35.14 million, setting a record for the neighborhood.

title: A Swanky Triplex In Soho
summary: Extensively renovated, the apartment features wood-burning fireplaces and lots of neutral tones. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Reopening Colleges Likely Fueled Covid-19 Significantly, Study Says
summary: Research suggests in-person classes led to thousands of additional cases each day in the U.S.. Colleges and universities that reopened for face-to-face instruction might have caused tens of thousands of additional cases of Covid-19 in recent weeks, according to a new study conducted by researchers at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, Indiana University, the University of Washington and Davidson College.

title: September Brings a Reality Check for Stocks
summary: Latest selloff has improved the balance between market performance and earnings expectations. September is living up to its well-known reputation as a poor month for stocks. Investors may grow to appreciate it.

title: An Airline Answers to a Higher Authority
summary: United Airlines made a scheduling change that conflicted with a Jewish holiday on a flight to Israel but, to a religious passenger's delight, fixed their schedule. Complaints about flying have been with us almost since Kitty Hawk, usually without results.

title: In New York City, Is It Cheaper to Hail a Taxi or Use a Ride-Share App?
summary: Amid the pandemic, fares on Uber and Lyft often are the same or higher than a yellow cab. With the weather cooling off and pandemic numbers dropping, New York City is slowly getting back in action-and that means people are hopping back into taxis, Ubers and Lyfts. But as riders are discovering, a lot changed in the for-hire ride scene during the coronavirus lockdown. Some may want to rethink their habits.

title: Wall Street Has an Obamacare Problem
summary: Health-care stocks could get hit hard if the Affordable Care Act is overturned by the Supreme Court. Uncertainty at the Supreme Court means a familiar and unwelcome risk has resurfaced for health-care stocks.

title: How to Make Friends in a New Place During the Covid-19 Pandemic
summary: It can be especially hard to reach out to people with coronavirus in the background-here's how to clear those social hurdles. When Catherine Dorman packed up her Chicago apartment to start a remote job in Washington, D.C., in May, it was hard to make friends. Nearly everyone the 25-year-old knew who lived there had left the city to be with their families. Bars, gyms and art classes weren't options anymore. Most of the face-to-face interactions she has had in the past four months have been with her two rescue cats, Stevie and Louise.

title: A Classic Lamborghini That Needs Its Own Talent Agent
summary: Resume Subscription. Matt Farah, 38, co-creator of the automotive-enthusiast podcast and YouTube channel The Smoking Tire and owner of Westside Collector Car Storage in Los Angeles, on his 1988 Lamborghini Countach 5000 QV, as told to A.J. Baime.

summary: Matt Farah shows off his 1988 Lamborghini Countach 5000 QV. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How a Fortunate Few Airlines Profit in a Pandemic: Lots of Cargo
summary: As Covid-19 eviscerates the travel business, airlines are swapping seats for freight space. SEOUL-The only major airlines making money these days are busy flying cargo, not passengers.

title: What You Need to Know About Herd Immunity
summary: The concept is at the heart of global vaccination efforts and discussions about next steps in fighting the Covid-19 pandemic. For the pandemic to end, the coronavirus has to run out of people to infect. When enough people in a population develop an immune response, either through previous infection or vaccination, herd immunity can be achieved. This makes it harder for the virus to spread and protects those who aren't immune.

title: Hot Oil Field Was Desperate for Pipelines. Now It Has Too Many.
summary: Permian Basin has become a headache for pipeline operators, with the pandemic further damping demand for crude. America's hottest oil region has too many pipelines and not enough oil to fill them, bad news for pipeline operators.

title: Your Kid's a Picky Eater? Apps and Meal Services Can Help
summary: Subscription plans encourage children to try new foods and get involved in meal preparation. In many homes, the most challenging question of the day is: "What's for dinner?" And when you have picky eaters or children with food allergies, the nightly decision-making can be downright fraught.

title: Tesla, Peloton, Nike: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens
summary: Tesla shares slid in premarket trading ahead of the much-anticipated Battery Day event.. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Tuesday.

title: LVMH Is Readying Its Red Pen for Tiffany's Books
summary: U.S. jewelry company can't put a foot wrong before the trial that will decide the fate of luxury's biggest deal. LVMH has gone quiet about the letter from the French government that was the original reason it cited for derailing the luxury sector's biggest-ever deal. As its focus shifts to Tiffany 's business performance, the U.S. jewelry company needs to tread carefully.

title: Elopement Makes a Major Comeback Amidst the Pandemic
summary: Who needs a 200-person guest list? Couples are cancelling their big days and getting hitched in secret. One bride reflects: "The best way to describe it-one of the most fun, memorable and stress-free days of our life.". After completely ditching the big summer wedding she planned and eloping with her fiance, Sam Wannemacher is relieved. "Once you've already spent a year and a half planning a 150-plus person wedding with tons of out-of-town guests and dozens of vendors to coordinate, planning a two-person elopement starts to feel shockingly simple, and a lot less expensive," she says. "The best way to describe it-one of the most fun, memorable and stress-free days of our life."

title: China's Luckin Coffee Is Fined for Inflating Results
summary: Commerce regulator imposes $9 million fine on two Luckin entities and 43 other companies that helped it falsify sales and expenses. China's top commerce regulator fined Luckin Coffee Inc. and dozens of companies that helped the coffee chain inflate its sales and expenses in 2019, wrapping up a monthslong investigation into the accounting misconduct at the once-highflying company.

title: Italian Bonds Rally on Election Results
summary: Yield on Italy's 10-year debt fell to the lowest level since October 2019. Italian bonds rallied after the nation's latest election results soothed investors' worries about its historically volatile politics and their impact on the eurozone.

title: Blackstone Ready to Lend After Raising Record Property Debt Fund
summary: Investment firm raises $8 billion as falling rates help increase appeal of relatively high-yielding real estate debt. Blackstone Group Inc. closed this month on the largest real-estate debt fund ever, giving the investment firm plenty of cash to lend to property investors looking to go shopping during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Real-Estate Investors Buying Studio Home of 'The Sopranos'
summary: Hackman Capital leads group that has signed a contract to pay $500 million for New York's Silvercup Studios. A group of investors is acquiring the New York studios where "The Sopranos," "30 Rock" and "Sex and the City" were filmed, the latest sign that real-estate owners are trying to capitalize on the growing popularity of streaming content.

title: Insurance Freeze Snarls U.S. Supply Chains
summary: Trade-credit insurance, a financial tool that protects global trade, has been severely curtailed due to Covid-19. An obscure part of the insurance industry that helps commodities flow smoothly around the world is seizing up, presenting another obstacle to the U.S. economy's fitful recovery.

title: Tokyo Olympics' Biggest Coronavirus Challenge Could Be Team USA
summary: Americans are usually the largest Games squad and the biggest winners. Their country also is among the most infected.. The U.S. has won more medals than any other nation in Olympic history. It usually has the largest contingent of athletes at the Summer Games. And it's the highest-value single market for Olympic broadcast rights, the International Olympic Committee's primary source of revenue.

title: Macau Casino Stocks Still Face Long Odds
summary: Macau is open to Chinese gamblers again but it may have trouble bringing in high rollers. After a brutal downturn during the early months of the pandemic, Macau's casinos will likely see more visitors soon. That doesn't necessarily make casino stocks a winning bet-at least not for a while.

title: Critic of Chinese Leader Sentenced to 18 Years in Prison
summary: Punishment of retired real-estate mogul is seen as a warning to others within Chinese elite. HONG KONG-A Beijing court sentenced an influential businessman known for his outspoken criticism of China's leader, Xi Jinping, to 18 years in prison, meting out harsh punishment in a corruption case that is likely to chill dissent within the Chinese political elite.

title: As Covid-19 Fatigue Fuels Infections in Europe, Italy Resists Second Wave
summary: Resume Subscription. Months after Italy's lockdown against the coronavirus ended, Enrica Grazioli still sanitizes everything that comes into her Milan apartment, wears face masks diligently and limits interactions between her sons and their grandparents.

title: Covid-19 Testing Is Hampered by Shortages of Critical Ingredient
summary: Lack of reagents is forcing health systems to limit who can get tested and end community testing programs. Supply shortages are forcing health systems across the country to limit who gets tested for Covid-19, hindering efforts to ramp up testing as flu season approaches.

title: Thousands of U.S. Troops to Take Part in Covid-19 Early-Detection Study
summary: A 'check engine light' for people: Defense Department partnering with Philips to find barely perceptible changes in troops' health.

title: Vatican Pushes Against Growing Acceptance of Euthanasia
summary: Document approved by Pope Francis denounces legalized euthanasia as intrinsically evil. ROME-The Vatican condemned the spreading international acceptance of euthanasia and assisted suicide, including in some traditionally Catholic countries in Europe, in a strongly worded document that reasserts traditional teaching.

title: China's Attack on 'Unreliable Entities' Is a Double-Edged Sword for Beijing
summary: Country has been slow to retaliate against U.S. commercial restrictions, illustrating that its options aren't great. The announcement by China's Commerce Ministry that its "unreliable entities" list is near completion has rippled through markets this week. But Beijing has been treading carefully in deploying such tools, and for good reason: Most would harm China more than the U.S.

title: Where Trump and Biden Stand on China
summary: Hard line on Beijing likely to continue regardless of U.S. election outcome. This article is part of a Wall Street Journal guide comparing President Donald Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden on issues from climate change to health care and jobs.

title: Orlando Bravo Rides Software Deals to Heights of Private-Equity Industry
summary: As companies reel from the pandemic, revenue at software providers owned by the Puerto Rican billionaire's firm has largely remained steady. Orlando Bravo has argued for years that software is so essential to business that companies won't stop paying for it, even in a crisis. The coronavirus pandemic has proven him out.

title: Laid-Off Workers Cut Spending as Extra Unemployment Benefits Run Out
summary: A short-term extension has been helpful but hasn't fully alleviated financial fears. When the coronavirus pandemic struck the U.S. in March, Caroline Mongillo lost her part-time job at a music venue and struggled to find new work in a labor market hampered by the health crisis. But like millions of other laid-off workers, she covered expenses with the $600 a week in extra unemployment benefits provided by the federal government.

title: Supreme Court Vacancy Leaves Many Voters Unmoved
summary: With most voters' political views entrenched this year, interviews found early signs that the fight over the Supreme Court vacancy isn't swaying many. WASHINGTON-As the partisan clash over replacing the late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg escalates, many voters around the country say the vacancy isn't influencing their choice for president or is just one of the issues they are weighing.

title: Corporate Compliance Programs Hit Refresh With Data-Analytics Tools
summary: Authorities show leniency to companies with data-driven anticorruption systems. The slow shift toward data-driven corporate compliance programs has a new accelerant: the government. Now, companies are scrambling to figure out how to meet the latest expectations.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Grand Chicago Hotel in Foreclosure, a Symbol of Covid-19's Toll on Hospitality Industry
summary: Thor Equities, owner of the Palmer House Hilton, is in default on its $333.2 million first mortgage, court papers say. The Palmer House Hilton has been one of Chicago's grandest hotels for more than a century. Oscar Wilde was a guest. Frank Sinatra serenaded diners at its supper club. Over the past 15 years, the owner spent $173 million to overhaul the hotel, modernizing most of the 1,641 rooms.

title: House Democrats Introduce Bill Funding Government Through Dec. 11
summary: Bill doesn't include farm aid sought by White House or an extension of Census deadlines. WASHINGTON-The House was expected to move Tuesday to pass a spending bill that would keep the government running through Dec. 11 but without farm-aid funds sought by the White House.

title: Former Police Chief Named to Assist Probe of Jacob Blake Shooting
summary: Wisconsin attorney general turns to former Madison official to help the Kenosha County district attorney. Wisconsin Attorney General Josh Kaul said Monday that a former Madison police chief will review evidence and provide a report to the Kenosha County district attorney before the prosecutor decides whether to bring charges against the police officer who shot Jacob Blake seven times in the back.

title: Trump to Make Supreme Court Nomination Over the Weekend
summary: President has five women under consideration to succeed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. President Trump said he was considering five women for the vacant Supreme Court seat and likely would make public the pick on Saturday, as Senate Republicans largely lined up behind him and rejected Democrats' calls to let the winner of the presidential election choose the nominee.

title: Getting Covid-19 Changed This New York City Family's Outlook on Virtual Learning
summary: Their ordeal led them to lose faith in the city's plans to keep students safe during the coronavirus pandemic. Najib Craig, 16, is among the 46% of New York City students who won't be going back into classrooms when part-time in-person instruction begins Oct. 1.

title: CDC Removes Guidelines Saying Coronavirus Can Spread From Tiny Air Particles
summary: Health agency removed the language, which had gone up on its website, saying it had posted a draft version of proposed changes in error. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention pulled new guidelines acknowledging the new coronavirus could be transmitted by tiny particles that linger in the air, saying a draft version of proposed changes was posted in error on the agency's website.
